metadata.title: Lymphedema Following Surgical Treatment for Breast Cancer
synonyms: medullary ductal carcinoma with lymphocytic infiltrate
description: Lymphedema occurs in an extremity when lymph flow is impaired. There is an excessive accumulation of protein-rich  interstitial fluid, usually as a result of an impairment of regional lymphatic drainage. Lymphedema following surgical treatment for breast cancer is considered a secondary form of lymphedema, whereas primary lymphedema involves a congenital malformation that impairs lymph flow.(2) In patients with breast cancer, lymphedema typically develops as a result of surgical treatment, which disrupts lymph channels. Lymphedema can also develop following radiation therapy.(1,2) The reported incidence of breast-cancer-related  lymphedema ranges from 6% to 65% due to lack of standardized diagnostic criteria, variations in assessment tools, and length of follow-up(8)

Lymphedema following surgical treatment for breast cancer is the most common form of lymphedema in the United States and usually occurs within the first year after surgery(11) –Risk factors for the development of lymphedema after surgical treatment for breast cancer include a high BMI, axillary surgery, radiation to breast and/or axilla, and the presence of positive nodes with diagnosis

ICD-10 codes.I97.2: postmastectomy lymphoedema syndrome (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. The United States Women’s Health and Cancer Rights Act of 1998 requires insurance companies to cover treatment for lymphedema related to surgical treatment for breast cancer(3)
presentation signs and symptoms: The edema usually is painless and progressive, beginning with smooth and pitting edema and progressing to non-pitting  edema. The skin is hard, thick, and leathery. Infections such as cellulitis, lymphangitis, or onychomycosis might be present. There can be drainage of the lymph(1) –Edema can be evaluated according to grades:(1,11) -Grade 0 – latent or no evidence of edema  -Grade 1 – spontaneously reversible - easily pits with pressure but is relieved with elevation, no evidence of fibrosis -Grade 2 – pits with pressure, but pitting is not relieved with elevation, some evidence of fibrosis -Grade 3 – edema is irreversible, with evidence of fibrosis and sclerosis of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, lymphostatic elephantiasis
Presentation might also include numbness and tingling; a feeling of fatigue, heaviness, pressure, or tightness in the affected area; loss of mobility and ROM; and impaired wound healing(4)
Aching, cramping, and paresthesia might be present Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: The therapist should closely follow the protocol of the patient’s physician

The clinician should keep in mind that other causes of edema include congestive heart failure (CHF), nephrosis, myxedema, hypoalbuminemia, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), chronic venous stasis, complex regional pain syndrome, and obstruction from abdominal or pelvic malignancy(1)
The patient’s pain threshold should be respected throughout the examination
Tell the physician if the patient has warm, tender, or painless enlarged lymph nodes(6)

causes: Disruption of the lymphatic system as a result of surgery for the management of breast cancer–Surgical procedures that can lead to lymphedema include:(1)-axillary lymph node dissection-mastectomy-lumpectomy-lymph node removal followed by radiation therapy
pathogenesis: This disorder is distinguished by an accumulation of lymph fluid in the tissues. This is the result of mechanicalinsufficiencies of the lymphatic system; the lymphatic system cannot manage the fluid in the body region affected
risk factors: Lymphedema remains a lifetime risk when the lymphatics have been compromised–Risk does not decrease over time

Risk factors can be divided into three main categories: treatment related, disease related, and patient related–Treatment related-Surgery-More involved surgical procedures/axillary node dissection-Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SNLB) was developed to prevent major complications such as lymphedema associatedwith axillary node dissection, and is associated with fewer complications and no significant differences in regionalrecurrence risk or survival compared with axillary node dissection(15,16)-SNLB has been endorsed as the preferred axillary staging procedure in patients with clinically node-negative  breastcancer-In a study conducted in the United States, disparities were noted in the rates of SNLB use, with Black patients’ ratesbeing 12 percentage points lower than White patients’ rates, which contributed to racial disparity in lymphedemarisk(16)-Radiation therapy-Chemotherapy-Combined treatment options–Disease related-Tumor stage at time of diagnosis-Pathological nodal status-Location of tumor in breast-Early onset of mild lymphedema is associated with significantly higher risk of developing moderate to severelymphedema(15)–Patient related-Age-Older age and premenopausal status-High BMI-Hypertension-History of infection or inflammation-Hand dominance-Occupation-Excessive use of affected limb-Genetics(15)-The reason only some patients develop lymphedema secondary to cancer treatment might be related to geneticcharacteristics-Polymorphisms in multiple candidate genes that appear to be associated with breast-cancer-related lymphedema havebeen identified

Chinese researchers developed a scoring system to predict the probability of lymphedema after axillary lymph nodedissection (ALND) utilizing 358 breast cancer patients surveyed for 12 months. They found that, with a cutoff value of 3,the sensitivity of the system was 81.2% and the specificity was 80.9%. The scoring was as follows:(21)–Level of ALND – 0 points for level I, 1 point for level II, 2 points for level III–History of hypertension – 0 points for no, 1 point for yes–Surgery on dominant arm – 0 points for no, 1 point for yes–Radiation – 0 points for no, 2 points for yes–Surgical infection/seroma – 0 points for no, 2 points for yes

Authors of a cohort study of 622 breast cancer patients in Brazil found that axillary dissection and the number of lymphnodes (≥ 15) were the main factors in the development of lymphedema within 10 years of treatment(22)

The clinician should keep in mind that other causes of edema include congestive heart failure (CHF), nephrosis, myxedema, hypoalbuminemia, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), chronic venous stasis, complex regional pain syndrome, and obstruction from abdominal or pelvic malignancy(1)
The patient’s pain threshold should be respected throughout the examination

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document type of surgery and any radiation or chemotherapy that the patient has had. Were lymph nodes removed? If so, how many? When did the lymphedema develop? How has it progressed since onset?

course of treatment.medical management: Has the patient received medical treatment for lymphedema and any underlying disorders? Does the patient have a selfcare  protocol? Is the patient adherent to the prescribed protocol?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Laboratory tests that might be performed include blood urea nitrogen (BUN), creatinine (Cr), thyroid function, urinalysis, liver function, and albumin tests
Imaging studies that might be performed include lymphoscintigraphy, CT scan, MRI, PET scans, and lymphangiography(1)
Dual-energy  X-ray  absorptiometry (DEXA) and bioimpedance spectroscopy are newer techniques developed to improve the clinical assessment of lymphedema(8)
In bioimpedance spectroscopy, resistance to low-frequency  electrical current within the extracellular fluid of the limbs is used to determine fluid volumes
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., cold pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Static and dependent positions of the lower extremities, sitting with legs crossed, use of heavy weights, vigorous or repetitive activity with the involved extremity, wearing restrictive clothing or tight jewelry, increased sodium intake, and hot environments might aggravate the condition.(6) Does anything ease the symptoms? (e.g., sleeping, stretching, bandaging)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Lymphedema usually involves one extremity but can involve both extremities depending on the etiology
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). The edema is usually painless and progressive, beginning as smooth and pitting and progressing to non-pitting.  Patient might complain of numbness and tingling or a feeling of fatigue, heaviness, pressure, or tightness in the affected area(4)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night -Ask about positioning of affected extremity in bed
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician. Skin infections might be present. There can be drainage of the lymph.(1) Emotional and psychosocial problems might occur and are reported to be unrelated to the severity of the swelling(9)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Any history of respiratory compromise? Smoking history? Shortness of breath? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe __________________________

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, other cancers, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she is be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Are long periods of standing or sitting required in the patient’s occupation? Does patient use heavy weights, perform vigorous or repetitive activity with the involved extremity, and/or wear restrictive clothing or tight jewelry? Is patient exposed to hot environments?(6) -Researchers in Canada interviewed 40 women with “arm morbidity” (i.e., pain, ROM restrictions, and lymphedema) 612  months post breast cancer surgery and found that women may experience an abrupt loss of previously enjoyed leisure activities with arm morbidity(23)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient use any assistive devices? Has the patient required assistance at home with functional mobility or ADLs? How much does the patient use the affected upper extremity during work and home activities? Is the affected extremity the dominant or nondominant side?
social and occupational history.living environment: Document information about the living situation, including number of stairs in the home, number of floors in home, and with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –BMI and girth measurements of the involved extremity -There is an association between increased body mass and lymphedema, so comprehensive treatment of lymphedema should include weight control(5) –Circumferential measurements should be compared with the uninvolved extremity -Generally, a 2cm difference in circumference between the two arms is considered indicative of edema -Factors that can bias circumferential measurements include weight gain or loss and arm dominance -Variables to consider include patient position; location and distance of measurement points along arm, hand, and fingers; type of tape measure used; and mathematical formula for calculating volume from girth(8) -Landmarks -Should be identified for girth measurement so they can be used throughout treatment -Anatomical landmarks might also increase reliability(6) -Use landmarks consistent with facility’s protocol(7) –Water displacement can also be used to measure volume -Psychometric properties of the water displacement method are excellent (excellent inter/intrarater reliability; good construct, criterion, and concurrent validity; and high sensitivity to detect small changes)(8) -Limitations include a tendency to overestimate in women with high BMIs, time requirements for setup and cleanup, and contraindications for its use in patients with skin breakdown and open wounds due to concern for cross-contamination  of infections(8) –Perometry is use of a noninvasive optoelectronic device that uses infrared light to quantify the volume of the limb(15) -Does not require direct contact with the limb, so is hygienic to use –Bioelectric impedance measures opposition to the flow of an electric current through the body. Impedance is inversely related to volume of the conductive material in the region(15) -Recording electrodes are placed on the skin at two points and bioimpedance spectroscopy is used to measure impedance over a variety of frequencies
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient require an assistive device and is it used correctly?
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess endurance using 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) as indicated. Fitness level is often reduced due to decreased physical activity and participation in leisure sports
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulse in both upper extremities and compareAssess with functional mobilityIs the patient able to perform functional mobility tasks independently? If not, might utilize the FIM
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Note gait deviations, need for assistance, and need for assistive deviceAssess mobility of joints of affected extremity and compare to other sideAssess upper extremity coordination as appropriate. Tests include finger to nose and rapid alternating movements(7) –Fine motor function might be diminished. Appropriate tests might include the Jebsen-Taylor  Hand Function Test, the 9-Hole  Peg Test, and the Boxes and Blocks test
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess upper extremities and trunk with manual muscle testing (MMT) and use of dynamometer(7)
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess the skin with the extremity in a dependent position and note the type, location, and severity of edema
Use grading system to grade edema(1,11)
Note changes in the skin (dryness is common), wounds, scars, and color. Document size, location, and mobility of scars. A photograph might be beneficial(6)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess in standing, sitting, and with functional mobility and note asymmetry –A comparative study of 20 women with moderate-severity lymphedema and 18 controls conducted in Turkey indicated that thesagittal thoracic curvature (P = 0.017) and the frontal inclination angle (P = 0.048) were higher in the lymphedema group in comparison with the control group(25)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess upper extremities and trunk. Has the edema limited the mobility of the joints of the involved extremity?Note ability to perform independently. Objective measures that might be used include the Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI)(7)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess light touch, pain, and proprioception of involved extremity. Compare to uninvolved extremity. Sensation might be impaired by the edema itself
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Bioelectric impedance spectroscopy (BIS) – a device to measure resistance to low-frequency  electrical current via skin electrodes has been developed for clinical use and has received approval from the U.S. FDA for use in the breast-cancer-related  lymphedema population(8) –Lymphedema Breast Cancer Questionnaire (LBCQ) – a self-report tool consisting of 19 yes/no questions on symptoms including heaviness, numbness, and swelling(8) -Has high test-retest  reliability and internal consistency is good, but responsiveness to change has not been demonstrated(8) –Morbidity Screening Tool (MST)–  a self-report  tool developed by a multidisciplinary team to identify fatigue, pain, upper limb dysfunction, and lymphedema after breast cancer treatment(9) -In a study conducted in the United Kingdom involving 613 participants who had completed treatment for breast cancer, the MST was found to have good construct validity when compared to the Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure, the Chronic Pain Grade Questionnaire (CPGQ), the LBCQ, and the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy questionnaire -MST was shown to be able to identify both early and late treatment-related  morbidity, thought to be important in this population because morbidity continues to impact patients’ lives –The Breast Cancer EDGE Task Force recommends the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy – Breast (FACT-B+4) and the DASH questionnaires to assess QOL and function in patients with breast-cancer-related  lymphedema(10)physical well-being,  emotional well-being, functional well-being,  social/family well-being,  and arm morbidity. The arm morbidity domain includes an arm subscale with questions on swelling and tenderness -Excellent reliability, internal consistency, and sensitivity to change have been reported(10)

contraindications precautions: In the United States, therapists can be certified by the Lymphology Association of North America (LANA) after completing an approved certification course(5)
Laser to the cardiac region of patients with heart disease
Infections, history of epilepsy, altered or impaired sensation

Avoid warm/hot water if patient is pregnant, or has multiple sclerosis, increased risk of hemorrhage (e.g., on anticoagulant medications), impaired thermal regulation, acute inflammation, fever, edema, thrombophlebitis, or acute rheumatoid arthritis
Open wounds, catheters, colostomies, IVs, G-tubes
More than half-body  immersion during pregnancy
other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
Maintain elevation of the involved extremity while sleeping, resting, during use of compression pump, and during sedentary activities
Extremely close attention should be paid to skin care because of the increased risk of skin breakdown, infection, and decreased wound healing
Avoid raising the body’s core temperature (in whirlpools, saunas, or hot baths)(6)
Therapists performing manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) should be specifically trained for this treatment method
Consult with physician prior to treatment if patient has CHF
There is some risk of infection with lymphedematous tissue

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Patients with lymphedema commonly present with increased girth of the affected extremity, decreased strength and ROM, and impaired sensation, balance, and function. Physical therapy might be beneficial to improve these deficits
prognosis: Authors of a study of 212 breast cancer survivors in India found that 49% had arm/shoulder problems as evaluated by the Kwan’s arm problem scale. The prevalence of arm/shoulder pain, lymphedema, and ROM deficits was found to be 12%, 27%, and 51%, respectively(26)

In a German study of 385 patients who underwent multimodal therapy for nodal positive breast cancer,23.5% experienced permanent lymphedema (stage II–III)  after a median follow-up  time of 10.1 years (range: 4.9–15.9 years).  Results also supported that axillary dissection and adjuvant chemotherapy put patients at more risk for lymphedema(27)
Lymphedema is a chronic, generally incurable condition that is manageable but is likely to require lifelong care.(1) Early intervention at stage 0 is thought to be key to better outcomes
Axillary dissection and the number of lymph nodes (≥ 15) were found to be the main factors in the development of lymphedema within 10 years of treatment(22)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Back to the physician for concerns or new issues. Occupational therapy for further assistance with ADLs and upper extremity dysfunction
other considerations: A higher stage of lymphedema correlates with a greater degree of limb volume difference, less balance, more kinesiophobia, and a greaterfear of falling(28) –Based on a Turkish study of 132 patients

Microsurgical reconstruction of the lymphatics performed by a plastic surgeon is a procedure that shows promise as a low-risk  surgical option for treatment of lymphedema(15) –The procedure involves creation of anastomoses, typically between lymph vessels and veins
treatment summary: Optimal treatment remains controversial.(15) Authors of a 2021 meta-analysis point out that there is no gold standard or consensus on treatment(29)

Authors of a 2020 systematic review and meta-analysis  concluded that MLD cannot significantly reduce or prevent lymphedema in patients after breast cancer surgery. The results did suggest that treatment with MLD of women < 60 years old within the first month of surgery may be effective(30) –Based on 17 RCTs involving 1911 patients

Comprehensive treatment regimens for lymphedema (complex decongestive therapy) have become the standard of care, including the following:(1,11) –Skin care management and treatment of infection –Specialized massage techniques to promote movement of lymph –Compression of the lymphedematous regions –Elevation and exercise to reduce swelling and supplement the massage

Complete decongestive therapy(1) –Some literature suggests that complete decongestive therapy (also known as complex therapy) is an effective treatment for lymphedema related to surgical treatment of breast cancer(4) -Complete decongestive therapy can be performed by trained healthcare professionals other than physical therapists (e.g., occupational therapists, nurses, physicians) -The overall goal is to improve drainage of the obstructed areas and to push the fluids to unobstructed areas(6) -Complete decongestive therapy has two phases(1) -The first phase involves MLD techniques that are performed by therapists with the goal of reducing the size of the extremity -The second phase involves maintenance of the limb size by the patient by performing self-care activities, including self-massage,  appropriate skin care, exercise, and the use of compression garments -Early complete decongestive therapy is more effective than education alone in preventing lymphedema related to surgical treatment for breast cancer(4) -Based on an RCT conducted in Spain of 120 women who had breast cancer surgery involving lymph node dissection -The women in the physical therapy group received complete decongestive physical therapy initiated 5 days after surgery and continued 3 days a week for 3 weeks -The women in the education group received lymphedema education only during the same time frame as the women in the physical therapy group

Therapeutic exercise –Authors of a systematic review found that that exercise can improve subjective and objective parameters in patients with lymphedema following surgical treatment for breast cancer, with the most positive effects provided by dynamic, moderate, high-frequency  exercise(31) -Based on 11 RCTS involving 458 women  –Therapeutic exercise and general physical activity neither worsen lymphedema nor increase the risk of the development of lymphedema related to surgical treatment for breast cancer -Contrary to earlier concerns, heavy load resistance does not cause or exacerbate breast-cancer-related lymphedema(12) -In a study conducted in Denmark involving 149 women who participated in progressive resistance training, there was no association between performing heavy resistance during adjuvant treatment and the development of lymphedema(12) -Although progressive resistive exercise was found to be safe for women in the first year after surgical treatment for breast cancer, results from an RCT indicated that it had no significant effect on lymphedema(32) -Based on a Danish study involving 158 women –Although therapeutic exercise on its own does not improve lymphedema in patients with postmastectomy lymphedema, it can improve shoulder ROM

Aquatic therapy –Authors of a 2018 systematic review determined that aquatic therapy had no significant benefit over traditional land-based exercise for improving lymphedema status or physical function in patients with upper extremity lymphedema after breast cancer. The authors suggested that patient preference should guide treatment choices(33)

LLLT –LLLT has been suggested as a complement to lymphedema treatment.(18) Its mechanism of action is poorly understood,but has been postulated to be related to stimulation of lymphangiogenesis, increased motility of the lymphatic system, and/or reduced lymphostatic fibrosis(18) -Authors of a systematic review of literature analyzing the effects of LLLT on upper limb lymphedema in women who have had surgical treatment of breast cancer concluded that LLLT had positive results with respect to reduction in circumference or volume of the affected limb(18) -Five RCTs with small samples ranging from 11 to 61 participants were included -Circumference was the main outcome in two of the studies and volume was the main outcome in three studies -Number of LLLT sessions ranged from 9 to 36 over periods ranging from 3 to 12 weeks. Duration of LLLT application was 17–20  minutes -Reductions in circumference and volume were reported in all five studies -The authors identified a need for more studies of high methodological quality . edema reduction: Girth measurements of the involved extremity

maintenance or prevention: Prevention Authors of a 2015 Cochrane systematic review of conservative interventions for preventing upper limb lymphedema analyzed 10 trials that involved 1,205 participants and concluded that(19) –current evidence does not allow firm conclusions about the effectiveness of MLD –the evidence does not indicate that there is a higher risk of lymphedema when shoulder mobilizing exercises are started early after surgery compared with delayed start (7 days after surgery) -Early start results in better shoulder mobility –the evidence suggests that progressive resistance exercise therapy does not increase the risk of developing lymphedema provided that symptoms are closely monitored and adequately treated if they occur Prevention recommendations include:(6) –keep limb moving. Avoid prolonged standing or sitting. Have feet flat on floor (no crossing legs) when sitting –avoid needle sticks (e.g., blood draws) and blood pressure measurements on the affected side –avoid limb constriction –elevate the limb –avoid air travel as much as possible and wear compression garments on flights –maintain normal body weight –avoid extremes of temperature and sunburns –exercise – previous recommendations against exercise have been disproved

Maintenance Patient to continue with self-management  of lymphedema to maintain edema-free  state, functional independence, and satisfactory QOL Many women find compliance with self-management  protocols to be problematic(13) Breast-cancer-related  self-care  guidelines are multifactorial and include a variety of modalities, including the following:(13) –Self-administered  lymphatic massage 4 times per week –Compression garments during all waking hours –Meticulous skin care daily –Pneumatic compression therapy 30 minutes daily In a study conducted in the United States, researchers found that breast-cancer-related  self-care  prescription varies from current clinical recommendations and that adherence to self-care  modalities is consistently low(13) Adherence to risk-management  behaviors in women at increased risk for developing lymphedema increased with increased knowledge about lymphedema risk management and greater confidence in their ability to manage lymphedema(20) –Based on a study conducted in the United States that involved 103 participants who had undergone breast and lymph node surgery –The findings indicated that information alone is not sufficient to motivate protective behaviors. The well-informed  woman also needed to hold positive views about her own ability to undertake the recommended strategies Researchers of a qualitative study conducted in the United Kingdom of 21 women in the breast-cancer-related  lymphedema self-management phase identified the following enablers and barriers to self-management:(24) –Being able to incorporate self-management  into daily routine –Recognizing the benefits of treatment and the consequences of non-treatment –Choosing to undertake self-management  – ownership  –Knowledge and understanding – knowing value of treatment, “listening to your body,” adjusting self-management activities to control symptoms –Problem-solving  – finding practical solutions, with hosiery creating the most challenges –Block – time required for treatment, especially for women with children and those who were employed full-time –Block – aesthetics of hosiery, both because it required them to explain why they are wearing and also reminded them of cancer Use of telerehabilitation to followup breast cancer survivors with lymphedema might improve self-care  adherence(14) –Authors of a study conducted in Spain found a high level of agreement between lymphedema assessment by telerehabilitation internet application and face-to-face assessment Skin care to control skin colonization with bacteria and fungi, eliminate overgrowth in crevices, and hydrate the skin to eliminate microfissuring should be emphasized(11) –Daily cleansing with mineral-oil-based  soap to remove debris and bacteria and to moisturize the skin is recommended Weight control(5)
